My wife has a Mr. Purple voice recording gadget by brandnewnoise. You should go get one now.

She loves it. She loves it more than me, I think. I don't blame her, I like it too.

Well the version that she got does not have a flag accessory, and she is very nervous that she will accidentally hit the record button and lose a favorite message.

Print these out so that you can disguise your Mr. Purple.

So she gave me a "honey-do" list this weekend, and I was able to finish it before the Super Bowl really got going.

I am sharing it with you.

Tooth paste has a fine grit.

A little too tight? The flag snaps onto the cap, and you glue the outside of the cap onto something. I had to work the flag back and forth, with a little toothpaste. Then washed it all off. I think that it should be tight, so the flag can be at any attitude.

Parameters

  • height: default 3.8mm
  • cutout: the width of the cutout of the ring, default: 2mm

Tests

author: CrazyCaribou

title: FEP punching template for Wanhao Duplicator 7 vat
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Either you dislike something, or just want to do it other way, whatever is, if produce good or better results and is simpler to do a task, that's a good reason to go for that.
It was also the case with replacing the FEP sheet on a Wanhao Duplicator 7 vat.
When I read the instructions it appeared to me you may have to have three hands or something. Moreover, many people complained of failed experiences. So, I though to my mind: it will come to me too! Well, then let's get prepared.

The attached template is used to mark on FEP the position of holes that are required to stretch the FEP sheet "drum tight".
The position is not exactly the position of holes in vat, but slightly shifted 1 mm away from the center - actually from the symmetry axes; should you want to be more exact, you can do some math and find more accurate positions ;)

Use a permanent marker to outline the holes. Make sure some kind of line is still visible on the FEB sheet since it is not so friendly with any liquid, and hence the usage :)

After marking use a punching tool, 4 mm diameter, to make the holes in the FEP sheet.

Then take each screw, pass it through the frame hole first, then through the corresponding hole in the FEP sheet. Don't mind it does not look nice, it shouldn't... yet.
When all screws are in place, put the entire assembly over the bottom of the vat and give each screw one turn into its own hole.
Afterwards, just tighten everything as seen in other tutorials. I've taken some pictures and I may prepare some detailed instructions if needed.

Note: Should you have questions, please comment in The Black Brother's page on Facebook. If you don't like Facebook, just try here, but chances are you'll get the answer... well, sometime in the future :)

print_settings.Printer:: Monoprice Mini Select V1/V2 & Malyan M200

title: Quick Bed Leveling and adhesion test

description.text:
Often, bed leveling with a piece of paper is fine. But what we actually care about is the resulting print quality. Printing this will let you inspect the distance between the nozzle and the printer bed at four corners and the middle of the build plate, giving you a good overview of your bed leveling quality.

Intended for printers with a 120 x 120 mm bed. The grid of the circles is 85 x 85 mm. The circles have a 15 mm diameter. This leaves 10 mm on all sides of the print for the user's nozzle priming code.

Two files are provided:

M200 Bed Leveling 0.2.STL
A one layer (0.2 mm) thickness set of 5 circles in an 85 x 85 grid. This should allow you to use whatever nozzle priming code you use on the sides of the bed without interacting with this print.

M200 Bed Leveling 0.2.STL EDGE
A thin edge is added to the circles to make it easier to remove them from the bed. Once you have things dialed in, the version without the edge will be difficult to remove.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini Select V1/V2 & Malyan M200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1, 0.175 or 0.2 layer height

Infill:

no
Print showing a good bed-nozzle distance on the top left and too little bed-nozzle distance on the lower right, causing the filament to deform and the nozzle to push into the filament while printing.

author: Smooth_MW

print_settings.Notes:: For the mount bracket and mount holdfast, I chose to print them with their long shafts pointing straight up. You will need supports under them as that surface is not critical,

description.text:
I had a manual Sherline Rotary Table (#3700) that I wanted to convert to CNC. This design is for a frame to secure a Stepper Motor to the Rotary Table's Worm gear's shaft, as well as a spider coupler to transmit the rotary forces from the stepper motor to the shaft.

You will need PLA material (or ABS) and TPU for the spider coupler. Apart from the 3D printed parts, you will also need:

1) A stepper motor. I used a 17HS4401 NEMA 17 Stepper Motor
2) 3 x M3x40mm screws - to secure the mount bracket to the mount holdfast, and then to motor frame
3) 4 x M3x5mm screws - to mount the stepper motor to the motor frame.
4) 2 x M3x10 screws - to secure the mount and shaft couplers to the stepper shaft and worm gear shaft
5) 7 (or possibly less) M3 nuts

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Simple Metal

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

All the printed parts can be of PLA or ABS, but the Spider should be printed with TPU or other compliant material.

For the mount bracket and mount holdfast, I chose to print them with their long shafts pointing straight up. You will need supports under them as that surface is not critical,

Post Process holes

All the holes will probably need to be widened up as they were designed to be a tight, snug, or even to be press fit. You will need drills of the correct sizes. The ones I needed were 5mm, 6.3mm, and 2.5mm for the stepper motor shaft, the worm gear shaft, and the M3 screws holes respectively.

The handwheel of the Rotary Table should be removed from the Worm Gear Shaft by removing the 2 screws holding it on.

The Mount Bracket and Mount Holdfast should be assembled on the Worm Gear housing, and secured with the M3x40 screw and nut. Check for wobble and shim with cardstock if necessary so that the wobble is minimized.

The Motor Frame should be mounted to the stepper motor with the 4 M3x5 screws.

The Motor Coupler should be mounted on the Stepper motor shaft, and secured with an M3x10 screw. The shaft should be flush, and should not protrude from the coupler.

The Shaft Coupler should be mounted on the Worm Gear shaft and secured with an M3x10 screw. The shaft should be flush, and should not protrude from the coupler.

The Spider should be placed on the Shaft Coupler.

The Motor Frame with Stepper Motor and Motor Coupler should then all be mounted to the Motor Bracket and Holdfast, making sure that the Spider Coupler is properly meshed with the Motor and Shaft Couplers. Secure together with 2 M3x40 screws and nuts. You may need to place 2 nuts per screw as spacers depending on the length of the stepper motors shaft.

Test by turning the motor coupler by hand and make sure that the worm gear moves. Any wobble or non-centricity of the motor shaft and worm gear shaft should be absorbed by the spider. Some wobbling is to be expected in the housing due to the lack of precision in the parts.

I hope it works as well for you as it does for me!

I did study some of the other designs to couple the stepper motor to the handwheel of a Sherline lathe. I did design a coupler to turn the handwheel, but I found the outcome to be unsatisfactory as the wobble was quite large. The turning of the handwheel via the handle is ultimately eccentric, so transmiting the forces that way was not ideal. I found that removing the handwheel was very simple (just don't lose the parts!), and coupling the shafts using a spider coupler was the best I could come up with.

I also wanted to have the Mount Bracket grip the Worm Gear housing tightly on 3 sides, so you'll notice that the Mount Holdfast has some sloped edges to transmit the forces correctly (it should be pulled IN to the housing as the screw is tightened). This didn't work as well for me as the tolerances were not good enough, and I didn't want to reprint the parts, so I ended up shimming the gaps.

description.text:
This is a complete case for the MeanWell RSP-500 power supply unit. If you want to print this you will need to complete:

Screws:
4x M3x10 buttonhead
8x M4x8 buttonhead

Electronics:
1x XT-90 female connector
1x IEC C14 connector, EAN: 4016138324730 (this one is I used: https://goo.gl/nV2HNW)
You can easily search the web for the EAN code, you will find the thing pretty easily.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2mm

Infill:

60%

Notes:

The lid simply prints flat on the printbed, keep in mind you need to place it on the bed that the cavity for the IEC C14 clips will face upwards.

The bottom housing prints standing upright, so that the XT-90 connector is 90° to the print surface. The same goes for the top housing.

You will need supports for the XT90 connector frame also for the corners where the threads of the screws go in to hold the lid.

I used a brim for the upright housings, 5 lines wide.

My housing was printed in black PETG.

After the print...

Depending on which XT90 connector brand you have used (mine came from hobbyking) the plug will have ripples on its side, those need to be filed off, the XT90 mount is designed to hold the plug without any glueing, so you need to file off only so much it is a very tight fit.

remixed_from.author: Bo_Ris
remixed_from.title: Adding MK3 heatbed to Vertex K8400

description.text:
This thing is a heatbed connector box for the Velleman Vertex K8400 that uses Anderson PowerPole connectors as well as Molex KK to connect the heatbed to the printer.

I made it compitable with Bo_Ris Wire covers, the one for mk3 heatbed (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2255250), but it also works fine standalone as shown in pictures.

You will need two pairs of Anderson PowerPole connectors, I used 30amp version, but 15 amp will work to, they use the same housing. These connectors work very well for this purpose as they are rated for high amps in a small housing and can be mounted in a box or be as is on a cable an are the same in both ends.
You can find them cheap on ebay, and you do not need the crimp plier, soldering works fine.

You will need a Molex KK connector for the thermistor cable, 2 pin 2.54 is what to look for, also chep on ebay, buy more of these as the fit on everything on these printers!

You will need 4 M3 10-12mm caphead screws for the housing itself to the printer

You will need 4 M3 12-14mm countersunk screws for the cover to the housing

Use glue to fasten the molex housing part to the housing as shown in the picture and solder on wires that will go to the motherboard.

title: Prusa MK2 Multi-Material MMU Idler screw gauge

description.text:
This is a simple little gauge that snaps over the springs on the idler screws to aid setting the proper distance between the washer and the idler printed part (4mm-5mm according to the assembly instructions). The gauge is 4.5mm wide, but measure it after you print it just to be sure. I have found that setting this distance accurately makes a noticeable improvement in the quality of prints on the MMU. Especially at higher print speeds. Hold in place and gently tighten the idler screws evenly until the gauge is just barely pinched between the washer and printed part. Once the distance is set, DON'T FORGET TO REMOVE THE GAUGE!

SET WITH NO FILAMENT IN EXTRUDER. < This is based on Prusa instructions, but mine seems to like being set WITH filament in the extruder.

author: tjcolejr

description.text:
This mod is yet another step in pushing Vertex printer to its limits. It increases print space along Y-axis to 218 mm.

NOTE: This design was created for VertexEvo. Ultimaker printer's glass, that I used, does not fit into the original K8400.

Brief story behind this mod: My original glass got damaged when one of the prints failed and I discovered that the only place to buy a replacement is on-line shop in UK that does not ship overseas. So, I started looking into other options and ended up buying the glass for Ultimaker UM2 that is over 10mm longer and wider than the original. I decided to benefit from this extra space and redesigned my glass holders published earlier.

I still don't know the exact dimension of Ultimaker's glass. The piece I bought on e-bay had trapezoidal shape - one side was 2mm wider than the opposite. Ultimaker uses metal clips to hold the glass in place and this difference would not matter, but when you use corner limiters it becomes a major issue. After about 2 hours of sanding the glass edges I made it rectangular with dimensions 256mm x 227mm x 4mm. If you decide to implement this mod - first buy the glass and measure it. Then, if needed, modify the .SAT files attached to this post to make sure the glass fits.

If you have my Camera mod installed the space gain will be less. It also depends on the shape of the print-head.

Here is the list of other related mods:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2427810
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2676231
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2414407
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2255250
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2243656
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1504426

Update 2-Feb-2018: I just discovered that upper part of the right side support is on the way of Y_visor when print head is within newly added space. While it is perfectly fine to have side support only from the left side, I will still redesign things to make sure they all fit together.

Update 8-Feb-2018: New Y-visor solving aforementioned issue is published here.

Printer:

VERTEX Evo

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

100% PETG

description.text:
Painter's Pyramids (aka Painter's Tripods) securely elevate your project off the work surface with minimal contact, allowing painted, stained or glued projects to be completed in one session with less mess and great results. The tabs allow temporary securing of the pyramid to your work surface (using screws, zip ties, tape, etc.) and they can be stacked for easy storage.

I've designed these to be printed without the need for supports or a raft. The length of each face is 2 3/8" and the teardrop design allows for airflow while offering homage to the art of painting.

Fun fact: The the Louvre has a Pyramid, too.

Enjoy! Comments always welcomed..

author: Trixigt

title: Wing Nut Grip for M3 screws (e.g. Anet A8 bed level screws)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I like the idea of having a simple grip around the M3 wing nuts of the a8 bed, leveling the bed without them, is just painful. Even though there are already designs, I didn't like the idea of the grip doing the job of the wing nut and being between the nut and the bed carrier. So I designed this grip, which is easy to print (no support needed) and it's really just a grip, the nut is still making contact with the bed carrier.
I recommend an infill of at least 30%, the nuts fit very tight into the grip, don't be afraid to push them in with a tool, I used a plier for it.
There are two different versions included, one very tight version (wingnut holder v10.stl) and one, that is a little less tight (wingnut holder v10 less tight.stl). I tried both, they work, using the less tight version makes pushing the nut screw in a little easier. Your choice ;)
Btw, just in case you want to use them on any other printer than the Anet A8, the diameter is 18.5mm.

Any suggestions, problems or ideas? Let me know in the comments :) You made one? I'd love to see some pictures :)

title: potentiometer servo controller glove
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
potentiometer glove to control servo
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YNxTY1SYrJU

10k ohm potentiometers where used to control the servos (large ones, part with the fastener is approx 9.5mm in diameter. Turn axle has a diameter of 6mm)
They are controlled with the arduino uno.
I have uploaded the ino and the electric layout.

If your going to start with building this you need to know the output from your potentiometer.
Because you don't have full range of motion.
Use the sketch from arduino tutorial to find the right output.
https://www.arduino.cc/en/Tutorial/AnalogReadSerial

The bracelet is modular and can be adjusted by using the small bracelet plates. So you can make it fit for your hand. The bracelet can be connected to each other using 1.75mm filament. At the end, place the endplate. There a 2 different types, you need both so they can hold the Velcro strips in place.
The distal finger parts are flexible. They need to be so when you flex your fingers they will stay fixed by the preload off the spring. There are 2 versions, i used the more flexible for the thumb.

------UPDATE--------
I have uploaded the skp file, this one contains a alternative finger spring design (not tested yet)

title: Kossel / Delta E3D Titan Clone Flying Extruder Mount

description.text:
Remixed from phili76's Titan 2020 extruder mount.

The Trianglelabs clone of the E3D Titan extruder didn't seem to have a flying extruder mount that fit properly, so I designed this one. I designed this to fit my Anycubic Kossel Pulley delta printer.

Additionally, there are mounts for surgical tubing (9mm OD, 6mm ID) for the suspension system of the flying extruder mount. The mount itself simply has M3 holes, any mount could be designed for different tubing etc. The surgical tubing mounts can be attached with M3x10mm screws (designed to countersink cap head style), and should be fastened with nylock nuts.

Tubing should be left slightly too long, not pulling between carriage and extruder mount. The Key-Bak should essentially make the extruder float weightlessly, the tubing is simply there to keep the extruder centered.

Video of the setup in action, so you can see how the extruder sits with the tubing. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iIOkIFi1THI

There is a recess in the middle/top of the mount for attaching a zip tie. To reduce the weight on the carriage assembly (an important problem as I have magnetic arms on my Kossel), I mounted a Key-Bak SUPER48, which basically neutralizes the weight of the flying extruder. I've included photo details to help show this.

Future plans:

  • Provide a mount for the Key-Bak, mine is sort of rigged up at the moment.
  • Provide a mount for the carriages; I used a leftover part from another project.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I used 3 outer perimeters to add strength.

comments.text:
Isn't the hole point of bowden to remove weight/mass from the system; which in this case is just re-positioned but still part of the moving mass more or less?
I'm not a bowden experct by any means, but I'd bet you;d be better off mounting your drive stationary to the side/top...
comments.author: Ottomation

comments.text: Yes the bowden tube setup is typically to reduce weight on the effector, so it can move faster without artifacting. However, the longer bowden tube setup requires high retraction distances, which not only slows down overall printing, but more importantly makes for less precise retraction due to slop in the bowden tube.
comments.author: Ottomation

comments.text: I posted this a while back, https://www.reddit.com/r/3Dprinting/comments/5tih4r/adding_some_kind_of_counter_weight_system_to_a/
comments.author: jharmn

comments.text: I guess what I'm getting at, is... it doesn't seem like your actually not really saving any mass, just morphing it?
comments.author: Ottomation

comments.text: You're effectivley changing the center of gravity by using the carriages to support the weight and task them with moving the distributed weight of the extruder assembly at the point of mechanical advantage.
comments.author: Ottomation

comments.text: There's not really enough room to squeeze the entire extruder assembly right against the effector, considering the range of movement the arms need. The short bowden tube gives just enough distance to allow for range of movement for the arms.
comments.author: Ottomation

title: Plastic Shelving Tool Organizers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I had a few of these super cheap plastic shelving units from Home Depot sitting around, so I've been using them to get some vertical space on my workbench. I developed these brackets so I could easily hang tools from their edges, right at eye level and above my work.

Note the profile of the shelf that these hook into; these aren't the bigger square-edged shelves. These shelves have a small lip sticking out that the brackets clip onto. They wont work with the square-front shelves.

The back brackets flex to allow installation, and to accommodate for the slightly varying depths in the shelves.

Comes with:

  • Small tool holder
  • Pliers holder
  • Clip leads holder
  • 3D printing tools holder

title: Jigs for cutting and drilling 2020 extrusion

description.text:
Cut jig
This is a simple but useful jig used for making precision cuts on 2020 extrusion. I wanted an easier and more precise way to cut these profiles, still just using a standard hack saw.

Slide the template on to the extrusion and align in to the correct position. Use a M5 bolt and t-nut to lock it in place. A hack saw with a good blade should give you a clean and precise cut.

Make sure that you don't cut past the extrusion and destroy the tool :-)

Drill jig
Align it with the edge of the extrusion, secure with a M5 bolt and a t-nut and then drill 3mm pilot hole(s). The template is intended for 2020 and 2040. The reason I haven't closed the end of this jig is to make it usable also on less precise end cuts, and to use it for centering holes away from the edge of the extrusion. It is also useful for centering the z-axis bolt on the y-axis extrusion on cartesian type printers.

Update 11.02.2018
Some small design changes to reduce the risk of cutting into the cut jig.

title: 20:1 Planetary Gearset Servo Drive InMoov Hip Joint

description.text:
I reused 6) Planet.STL, 1) Ring.STL from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2335266
The input and output shafts are HEX and 14mm (heavier)
I re-designed the Carrier (now InputGearPlate) to keep the gears of the two stages from binding on each other and make what used to be the SunGear a part of that plate.
The gearbox is very quiet and runs smooth if you grease everything up.
I'm using HS-5805MG Servo for the drive. The pot is removed & used for external feedback. The servo is altered for continuous rotation. I've also ported wires to the motor contacts so I can drive a slave in the robot ankles, creating the effect of parallelogram legs. The gearbox is 20:1 so torque increases dramatically.
I've enlarged the sun gears for less play. Scale if needed based on your print results.

There are brackets for mounting the assembly to my current InMoov & legs setup. The output shaft is held firm so the gearbox itself produces the output motion. The big pin inserts into the rest of the part of the hip joint which allows for flexion and extension at the hip. I've built a set of legs for my InMoov which I will publish once I have her walking. My plan is to use this in my InMoov's hip & ankle joints for lateral weight shifting, an absolute must if the InMoov is to walk. I am a retired PT and know quite a bit about the human gait sequence.

Let me know if the images and video provide enough info for assembly.
Video: https://youtu.be/tiQeYsx9oTM

Hardware:
6) M4 x 10mm Hex Cap Screws - Gears
6) #8 x 5/8" Sheet Metal Screws - Covers
10) Large Servo Screws (from Mega's) - Servo, Servo Wheel, HipPlanetPotBar
2) M3 x 20mm Machine Screws - Servo Riser mounting
1) Small 6mm machine screw - HipPlanetPotArm

2/6/18 Considering design changes to make the assembly more compact and the drive and output shafts heavier. Will upload as needed & post notes of changes.

2/18/18 New shorter and adjustable version of HipPlanetPotArm & HipPlanetPotBar - print both with support.
2/19/18 Combined three parts (Carrier, Separator, Sun Gear) into one: InputGearPlate
2/20/18 Revised covers to lessen input/output shaft play. Am testing inner bearing surface for input sun gear... we'll see.
2/27/18

  1. Yep - the inner bearing surface on the input gear is a good addition so InputGearPlate and SunGear are both new.
  2. For High torque output applications the OutputGearPlate_v2.stl is replaced with OutputGearPlate_v2.stl along with a cover to match, Cover-36mm v2.stl and HipPlanetMount_SQ.stl
  3. To tighten up the backlash even more I've scaled the Planet gears 4% larger.

Printer:

MakerFarm Pegasus 8"

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

.4

Notes:

author: dsob

title: Gameboy Advance SP Extended Capacity Battery Cover

description.text:
I tweaked the original cover from sheshin but I expanded it to hide a 2Ah turnigy battery from hobby king and I included a mount for a micro usb breakout board for charging.

These are the parts I used:

  • Micro USB Breakout Board: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/5pcs-Mini-Micro-USB-to-DIP-2-54mm-Adapter-Connector-Module-Board-Panel-Female-5-Pin/32555774957.html
  • 2 Ah LiPo Battery: https://hobbyking.com/en_us/turnigy-2000mah-1s-1c-lipoly-w-2-pin-jst-ph-connector.html

Warning: Completing this mod requires irreversible, modification to the Gameboy Advance SP. You have to permanently remove portions of the lower housing to fit the battery snugly, even with the cover since the battery will sit at an angle. I recommend using an aftermarket housing. Soldering is REQUIRED.

You have to remove the entirety of the internal battery tray on the lower housing near the cartridge connector. You must leave the other side intact otherwise the shoulder buttons will no longer install properly. After making physical room for the battery, I removed the battery connector from the motherboard and the JST connector from the battery and soldered the battery to the bare pads. Using a connector would be optimal but I have not yet found one that will fit properly and is skookum enough. I used hot glue on the soldered terminals to secure the wires. You can solder directly to the battery connector on the SP without removing it, but I opted to remove it since it will give me a little bit more room to work with and it will make the mod reversible as long as I replace the lower housing and do not lose the desoldered connector. Until final assembly, the battery should always remain disconnected from the circuit board to protect from shorts.

To add the Micro USB breakout board for charging, solder stranded wire (28 gauge is sufficient) to the VBUS and GND pads on the breakout board and connect the VBUS wire to pin 2 on the reverse of the power port and GND to pin 6. Make sure you use enough wire to maneuver the board through the hole made for the battery, around the battery and into the battery cover. I find that a service loop will give enough slack to maneuver the components and it will tuck neatly underneath the rear of the battery or to the right side.

This is my first 3D printed part and first thingiverse contribution so bare with me
i have uploaded the stl file but can upload solid if required for remixes
its quite tight on the spindle which is deliberate as there is no screw, it does fit though.
i used PPLA on an ultimaker 2+ at reading makerspace
i ran it at 10% infill and 0.15mm layer height.
i used the default pla settings for feed speed and heat
it feels a little flimsy but it has held up well so far but i can foresee it getting a bit brittle in the sun.
its for a 1973 bay window but id imagine these air vents are fitted to all kinds of campers so might fit all sorts!

i designed it using a 3d modelling software called onshape its free to use as long as you don't mind your designs being in the public domain (you can pay to keep them private) and you don't even need a good computer because its all online!
i was very impressed with it so if you've not used it before have a go! it behaves very much like solidworks and i think its made by the same people

title: CR-10 Mini Semi Auto Leveling G-Code

description.text:
Download and run the CR-10 Mini Semi Auto Leveling Code.gcode file

Be ready with your paper so you can set it in place before it hits Z0 at each corner.

This is a Semi Auto Leveling procedure for the Creality CR-10 Mini.
It will go to the home position and then to all four corners () and wait 15 seconds while you make the adjustment to each leveling wheel with your test gauge paper. The printer will beep 3 times before each move so you are not caught with your fingers in the wrong place at the wrong time :-). 3 quick beeps when the procedure is complete.

I like to heat the bed before leveling. The G-code has the heat disabled by default.
Uncomment it in the G-code if you want to use heat before leveling. The procedure will wait for the bed to achieve to set temperature before continuing.

BTW. If you ever take the cover off the controller, put a few layers of tape over the speaker hole. REALLY knocks down the squeal of those beeps.

WARNING!
Your bed should ALREADY be VERY close to level BEFORE running this procedure.
This is meant for a quick routine tune-up of an already previously manually leveled bed.

Printer:

Creality CR-10 Mini

Resolution:

None

Infill:

None

Notes:

WARNING!
Your bed should ALREADY be VERY close to level BEFORE running this procedure.
This is meant for a quick routine tune-up of an already previously manually leveled bed.

comments.text:
In your "Read Me" file and your comments here you say the bed heater is off by default but the first line of your Gcode says
;M190 S60 ; Set bed heat to 60 & Wait
Doesn't that mean that the bed will heat up when I run the program?
Is it more accurate to level the bed when it is hot?
comments.author: Celltech56

comments.text:
The ";" is a comment mark. Anything after a comment is disabled or ignored in a script
Remove the begining comment mark ----> ; if you want a heated bed.

title: Bed frame fix,anet A8, Prusa I3

description.text:
i have an acrylic bed frame and it is a pain, it will bend when it get hot and mess with the level, to make things worst the frame warp so much than it will touch the frame of the printer.
i have tried making new holes for add an extra bearing to fix it and at same time make an stable bed, but i mess up and make the holes in the wrong plase for less than one MM causing pression on the bearing and the bed frame.
without any other option i have to print my way out. so i designed a long bearing case capable of soport the bed usin the standat holes so it will not required new modification.
it works better than i thought. it will support the bed so well you will not have the leveling your bed so often.
you will not need to change all your standard bearing case, i designed it with the standard height of the SC8UU bearing so it will fit just fine.
but in case than you want to i maked a single bearing version.

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

30

Notes:

print in ABS not only because it will not warp with the heat olso the holes for the screw are really tight to allow a nice pressure, with PLA it will not be possible.
just hit the print button and get yourselve a couple of nylon strip zip (3MM X 100MM) and a lm8uu bearing.
since the bed is acrylic you can add double sided tape to increase the addition.

This phone mount works with any smartphone and has also been tested with iPads. It prints in 4 parts: the main body, spring, and two support arms. In my print, I used ABS for the spring and arms, and PET-G for the body. The tolerances between the parts are set to 0 so you will have to do some light sanding in order to get the parts to fit. As for attaching it to a tripod, there is a cutout for a 1/4" nut to get epoxied into place (or you can download a nut from my page).

After seeing a video on youtube about an airhorne made in wood (search for 'obnoxious air horn'), I decided I would try and print one myself from the same approximate measurements.
After finding thing 2859 and finding it to be inadequate and not properly designed (middle tube should protude a little from the outside edge, and the hole in the side should have been included in the model) I decided to crank one together myself.

Printed on an UM original. 0.8mm top and bottom layer, reasonable thick walls (at least 0.8mm) and 40% infill (less might be ok as well) at 90mm/s.  
Wrap a balloon over the top (where the middle tube is protruding) and fold it back so the balloon is tightly fitted with no wrinkles (pictures will follow). This takes a little practice the first time as you might feel like you need a 3rd hand.  
Blow hard into the hole in the side. Adjust balloon for proper tone and remember - this thing is loud!

So I originally only made this an an upgrade for my own printer, but by popular demand I have decided to upload it for every one to share.

The idea is simple, I use allot of Rigid Ink 300g spools that have a 50mm inner diameter, but my spool holder is 30mm so I designed this adaptor to save changing the spool holder for each spool.

It comes as one half and would need to be printed twice of course but both half's are the same so that wont be an issue, you will also need 4 4mm x 1mm rare earth magnets that fit pretty snug when printed correctly but may still need a spot of glue to hold them in (or just simply glue both half's together permanently, if you have the space to still slip it onto your holder)

title: Creality CR-10 base plate fan mod

description.text:
I was annoyed by the fans of my printer, so I started replacing them. I found the concept of the fans in the control-box not good, and I wanted to use a bigger PC fan. So I removed all fans of the control box. I removed the base plate/bottom of the power supply, so that the fan I mount from the bottom can blow directly into the power supply and the other areas at the same time.
After that I used tape to close the first half of the slots at the side of the control box (see pictures).
The concept of my design is that the fan pushes air into the control box. Some of the air flows to the very top and some to the bottom through the PSU - as the fan is positioned. than the air goes to the back of the controllbox where it is released. I testet the design with some smoke and it works good. The main advantage is that you only need one 120mm fan.
First I used an enermax magma. But I ended using a BeQuiet PurePower I had laying around. The BeQuiet is an excelent choice as the air pressure is high enough and its quiet at the same time.

The first print (white) was just a "proof of concept" to see if everything fits. Thisone I printed with 10% infill - which is NOT enough (I hat to use some tape to fix it)
To print I recommend cura with cubic subdevision as infill method and support only touching build plate. I neededd around 550g of PLA while using 80% infill. The result is unbreakable :D I attached my gcode so that you could directly print it out with an CR-10. Just make shure to adjust the temperature while printing to match your filament.

You can use the screws of the original base plate, no need to actually buy something else than the fan. To connect the new fan you can use a Wago 221-412 connector or solder it, but the best option is a Noctua OmniJoin Kit (noctua.at/de/omnijoin_adaptor_set) which was included in another fan I bought for my cr10 (Noctua NF A4x10 FLX).

Let me know what you think!

Thanks
Hans

Inspired by the original iPhone Lightning Dock by Apple (www.apple.com/de/shop/product/MQHX2ZM/A/iphone-lightning-dock) and the wonderful design of jckray (www.thingiverse.com/thing:1713891) I wanted to design my own iPhone dock. The design of Apple works with the Apple cases but not with cases of for example Spigen and a lot of other cases. The design of jckray was great, but the version wich is ment to fit most cases did not fit 5 different (slim) cases i own. Maybe just bad luck, but I decided to do something about it.
As I didn't want to use original Apple Lightning cables (which fits perfectly in jckrays design) I chose Amazon basics Lightning cables (which were to loose in jckrays design).

The result is a nice dock with custom text and my logo at the front. You have to use the base plate of jckrays original design. The other stuff is not exactly a remix as I build it from scratch, but it sure is inspired by jckrays design.

How to print:

  • Print the STL file, no support needed (I used 65% cubic subdivision infill in cura).
  • Print the base plate (www.thingiverse.com/thing:1713891)
  • Put something heavy in the two big grooves (just to make the dock a bit heavier). I used some lead powder and glued it in with hot glue
  • Attache the amazon basics cable available in black or white (https://www.amazon.de/AmazonBasics-Ladekabel-Lightning-zertifiziert-Apple-Wei%C3%9F/dp/B017YEAR0C/ref=sr_1_4?ie=UTF8&qid=1517782853&sr=8-4&keywords=amazon%2Bbasics%2Blightning%2Bkabel&th=1)
  • Attache the base plate (for attaching the cable and the base plate is no glue needed, just a little bit of pressure...

In the pictures you see two test prints, I had no final thing to photograph as it was a gift and I forgot to take a picture^^. Hope you like the design!
Included are two STLs: One blank and one with "Hab dich lieb" writen on it. The text can be easily modified in freecad.

Hope you like the design!
Thanks
Hans

All the parts are now cut and oriented in a way that they can be printed supportless (exeption: the hinge mechanism, but it only needs very feew support). It consists out of 55 different parts that need to be printed. They are all contained in the new Iron Man Helment optimized_v2.zip file.
--update above-- I wanted to print the IronMan Helmet. But I only own an Huxley 3d Printer, which only allows me to print on a platform roughly 13 by 13 cm and about 9 cm high. So at first I wanted to do a small scale version of my model, which by the way is completely by me! I didn't copy anything existing on the web, and I actually think my moddelling has worked out quite nice! The small version has roughly those measures: 11x14x16 I implemented a small hinge, to allow the mask to open, just the way it opened in the movies. But the small version wasn't enough for me, so I scaled it up until a real human had would fit inside. The measures now are 23x30x33.3 cm. There is some room for inserting foam or sth similar, to make wearing it more comfortable. But now I had the problem that such a large object wouldn't fit on my huxley printing bed. So I split up the model in many small pieces and layed them out in the most efficient way so all parts could be printed on my Huxley. I also uploaded the complete assembled helmet and mask in large scale, if you want to split it up yourself! I hope you like it! Please send pictures of your printout! Thanks! If you enjoy my work, I would appreciate a small bitcoin donation to 1MSachsBbZJjBg83nEsTv95oLuQmnmZnGu. Also please contact me if there are intersections or missing parts! Thanks :) -- Improovement --
Naarzaul has added an additional piece to the jaw section to add a detail to make it look much more like the original version. You can find it here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33304 ---ATTENTION!!---
The scale of the overall model is a little too big! You should scale it down by about 10 to 15% (some even say 20) to get a better size and save material. Sorry for everyone who has printed it in the large scale..

---ATTENTION!!---
The scale of the overall model is a little too big! You should scale it down by about 5 to 15% (some even say 20) to get a better size and save material. Sorry for everyone who has printed it in the large scale.. Make sure to also download the Largescale_jaw_part2 file. Unfortunately it is missing in the zip folder. Print out all the parts, puzzle the parts together, glue them in place, sand off any access, and paint, or maybe you printed in the right color directly! I think there is a golden pla available.. For the small scale version use the HelmPar1 and Part 2, the jaw.stl and the mask.stl. Those fit together at the same scale. For the large scale version use the Largescale..part1, part 2 and so on.. I know.. those are many parts! :D But if you have a larger Printingbed then I do you might be able to rearange several parts into one! If you have trouble fitting the pieces together: in the included .blend file you can see how they should be put together. --TIP--
To make the assembly easier you might want to write the name of each piece on them. It helps you find them later. I also would recommend you not to print everything at once, but start with all the mask parts then assemble then print the jaw parts and so on. This makes it easier to distinguish different parts. ---ATTENTION!!---
The scale of the overall model is a little too big! You should scale it down by about 10 to 15% (some even say 20) to get a better size and save material. Sorry for everyone who has printed it in the large scale..

title: Fire Raptor conversion for Storm Eagle

description.text:
Hi,

Following a request, and having thought about for a while, Here is a kit to convert my Storm Eagle proxy into a Fireraptor ! It is not 100% accurate, but it should do the job.

== If you like my work please consider sending me some tips ==

update 05/02/2018 : corrected Avenger_cannon (mesh error) and turret_cannon+turret_base (hard to fit)
update 11/02/2018 : added a turret with dual bolter (thank you crocoloco)

Basically here is what you need to change :
On the front of the storm eagle :

  • remove the front door
  • install the avenger bolt cannons inside the hole
  • glue the avenger_back part at the back of the lower part of the front (optional)
  • replace the 2 front bolters with sensors on the small front turret

On the back of the storm eagle :

  • remove lateral doors
  • install the turret base instead (print 1 + 1 mirrored)
  • 2 different turrets :
    • plug the dual bolter turrets on the base (print 1 + 1mirrored)
      or
    • plug the turret on the base (print 1 + 1mirrored)
    • plug the weapons on the turrets (print 2x2 cannons)

I'll try to add some more parts on the kit, in particular the replacement for the rocket launchers on the top. and some other variants for the side turrets weapons.

and now have fun !

Copyright infringement is not intended. All parts are created freehand in 3d modeling software, no copyrighted product had been scanned or copied in any way.

description.text:
2-8-18 - Latest revision uploaded.

This is a quick project that was a long time coming. For over a year I have had a messy desk with tools scattered all about. I have been needing something to organize so I designed one. But, this is for what I needed. Still, it may apply to you as well.

On the left side there is an ascending Allen Wrench column that goes from 1.5mm to 5mm. Again, this is for my drivers with handles. Any Allens will fit.

On the right side there is an ascending column of drill bits. They are Standard bit's but would fit Metric as well. Mine is 1/16th to 1/2". Next to the drill bits I have a recess for sanding sticks.

On the back there is a slot for the BondTak Spatula (that you all should have).

The ascending compartments are for whatever you please.

This is for my needs, but I am sure it will work for anyone who has a bunch of tools that need to be corralled.

Thanks.

remixed_from.title: Ball and Socket LED Lamp for 10mm x 50mm LED Strip Sections

title: Easier to print Ball and Socket LED Lamp Link STL and All-in-one

description.text:
This is an all in one print (which I did on and for the Tronxy X1) for a ball and socket LED light. It uses 5050 white LEDs (two sections worth, 6 individual LEDs) and is useful for lighting up the build surface of the printer so that a camera is useful when the room lights are off.

I soldered the power for the light right to the 12v jack coming in to the printer so that when the printer is plugged in, the light is on.

This also provides a re-uploaded version of the OBJ file in the source project, in STL format both with and without a brim to make printing easier.

Update: Added all in one STL for 10x50 (5050) LED strips with 10 ball and socket links, base and lamp end. This project took a lot more effort to print because each link had to be printed individually. This makes it easy to print all at once.

Make sure you have really good adhesion as the links can be tricky to get stuck down. I used glue stick on blue tape.

Update: Added a built in brim that is meant to be broken off of each of the links

Update: Added Single Link with Brim built in

Files:

  • LED_Lamp_All_In_One.stl - A base, 10x50 (5050) led strip head, and 10 links (complete lamp)
  • Link_With_Brim.stl - A single link with an added brim to make printing easier
  • Ball_link.obj.stl - The original, unmodified link with no brim, only converted to STL
  • LED_Lamp_All_In_One_Small_Bed.stl - A base, 10x50 (5050) led strip head, and 10 links (complete lamp) - Fits in 120mm x 120mm x 120mm for MP Select Mini

Printer:

Tronxy X1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 - 0.3

Infill:

20 - 30 %

Break or cut away the brim around the links and assemble the lamp. Feed the wires through the holes and links as you go. I recommend tying the wires together at the starting end so you don't pull them through as you add links.

If any of the links are too loose, put some masking tape around the ball to tighten it up.

print_settings.Notes:: The inlay design is all in one STL file, since it's a fairly quick print I just printed it three times in the different colors.

description.text:
Jewelry box with inlay design in the cover. Printed in Hatchbox wood.

A total of about 35 hours of printing and another 8 hours of post printing work went into this.

Printer:

Monoprice V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Notes:

Cover was printed with 50% infill, though not sure it needs to be that high. All other parts were at 20% infill.

Hatchbox wood printed at 210 degrees, 60 degree build plate.

Note that the inlay is 0.2mm smaller than the groove in the cover, which worked for me to get a tight press fit. But if it doesn't fit for you, I don't recommend shrinking the inlay with your slicer since that would also shrink the inner diameter. You could, however, play with your slicer z-axis scaling if you want the inlay to sit either deeper or higher in the groove.

The inlay design is all in one STL file, since it's a fairly quick print I just printed it three times in the different colors.

Wood post printing

Sanded to mostly smooth using 220 grit paper, but left a little texture to take the stain. Stained with Minwax Red Oak #215.

One of the more time consuming aspects of this project is getting a nice fit on the inlay. My printer left a small lip on the bottom of the inlay, probably could minimize this with by adjusting initial layer thickness and build plate calibration. But to get a good fit I had to use a precision file to round off the bottom edges before pressing into the jewelry box top. I went with press fix only, no glue. I used a roller to do the final adjustment.

The box cover insert is super-glued to the underside of the box cover. The cover is designed with a 2mm deep groove to align the insert, though my print resulted in that groove filling in so I had to eyeball it with slightly less than perfect results. I'm not sure if building the cover using supports enabled would help keep that groove intact. I had previously printed in PLA with much better results.

Design

All parts designed using TinkerCad.

description.text:
I needed a variable power supply for a voltage regulator and for a robot I'm working on. I thought about ordering several lithium Ion battery packs and wiring them up when I realized I had half a dozen packs for my tools why not utilize them. hence this cap.
I used keystone 204 battery clips and soldered a fused connector to each. they slide right on the print and it pops right on the battery. I did notice with some of the stiffer clips (depends on supplier) it helps to scale to 102% or 103% it will still be snug because of how tight the battery clips are. Here's a link to the 20 pack I got I'm sure there are several dozen places to get them, or just rip them out of some broken remote the should all work about the same. If your contacts are larger I'm happy to modify.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00XYSUURS/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

description.text:
Thought I should make something different to test out some new silk filament I got so here is a vase just in time for your lady for valentines day.

Just added a thin walled version with an internal fillet at the base. I did this after a friend printed with a .4 mm nozzle and said it was very delicate at the joint between the base and side wall. This should eliminate it. I labeled it so you can tell the difference Happy Printing!!!!

ignore the stringing on the inside of the vase it is a result of spiral settings where the fillet face meets the thinner side wall. if you have slight problems with water tightness I have found that flex seal white or clear sprays tend to seal it nicely and allow it to be water tight.

title: Latice Board Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Designed by Brent Vincent. Latice is a strategy game where you match tiles by color and shape. The game comes with a game board, stones, and acrylic tiles. Most of the tiles contain one of six images (e.g., turtle, leaf, lizard, dolphin) in one of six colors. There are also a few special wind tiles. The game is for 2-4 players, who will evenly split the tiles. You win by being the first player to play all of your tiles.

The first player selects one tile from their rack and places it in the center square on the board. The next player, and then each in turn, can add one tile to the board, but that tile must be set adjacent to one or more existing tiles, and it must match each adjacent tile based on either color or shape. If you match more than one tile, or you place your tile on one of the sun squares on the board, you get stones that can be traded in for extra moves, allowing you to get rid of your tiles faster. You can also use the special wind tiles to move a tile already on the board over by one square.

As you play Latice, you’ll learn to plan your turns and extra moves ahead of time. You’ll strategically use wind tiles to alter the layout of the board, and play both offensively and defensively based on your knowledge of the remaining tiles. Latice has no language, culture, age or gender barriers and can be played by just about anyone. It offers strategic gameplay for adults while still being simple enough for younger players.

title: Fabric spikes (and how to)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
*Photo of this print courtesy of Tyler Klene

Everyones printing on fabric now! its like the new hairy lion....

If you actually go back through youtube, guys figured this out years ago. For some reason it's back in style again so here are some easy ones to test if you want to give it a go. They are aligned so you can print multiple out and space them evenly.

A small example of what you can make in blender in around 12 seconds.

  • Create 1 horn
  • use the array modifier, multiply the object, apply.
  • Shift-D Duplicate that row, rotate it 90' sideways.

  • Move it to the right or left to alternate spikes like scales so they are not all in a plain row.
    OR you can use the offset feature that you can see in the Array modifier for precise origins.)

  • Join the two together CTRL-J, CTRL-A reset its rotation
    Add the array modifier again and choose how many rows you want.
    Finished.

Print layers 1-3 on the bed, lay fabric down (TIGHT!) print layers 4 onward.

Tip -
Ideally use masking tape or tape on your print bed so when you're done you can peel the tape off rather than trying to reef the fabric off to get the under layers off the bed too without ripping the fabric.

You also may need to re-centre this model on your build plate, I had it about 1mm lower than the plate.

title: 62mm slip on filter holder  for Litton 3x afocal Night Vision lens

description.text:
This allows the use of 62mm filters for the Litton 3x afocal night vision lens (USGI MX-11683/U). I used a Calumet 62mm UV filter and broke the glass for the ring. The ring snap presses into a groove in the printed filter holder allowing you a 62mm filter thread.

The filter holder slips on top of the 3x afocal lens. Dust covers are included as well.

I use this to filter out light pollution with a 645nm longpass filter from Midwest Optical.

Use glue to it in place, you may need to sand depending on your printer. Assembly 1(2) shows the Atlatl with a meter long dart. Print at 100% infill in order to get weight into your throw.

title: Shelf Board Support for IKEA Ivar

description.text:
This thing is for mounting shelf boards of arbitray length to your IKEA Ivar shelf.

There are two versions. With BoardSupportNormal.stl the board will be at the same level as the original shelf boards. BoardSupportOffset.stl raises the board halfways to the next level.

For each board you will need four supports, two of them printed as is and the other two mirrored around the x-axis.

DrillTemplate.stl if for marking the location of the 5mm fixing holes that need to be drilled into the lower side of the board.

You will also need the appropriate metal pins. They can be found on ebay, or you buy a 6mm round bar at your local hardware store and cut 40mm pieces from it.

author: veni_vidi_construi

print_settings.Notes:: All together I used about 585g of plastic, but that should go down slightly bit since I lowered the fan mount a bit after I printed mine.

description.text:
In my quest to make my printer more quiet, I came up with this idea since the i liked the power supply cover by ml_blh. (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2715000). I installed his cover and 2 new fans. Just doing that decreased the frequency of the PSU fan on time. (also quieter fans are more quiet.) The only trouble with the PSU cover was the base bottom cover did not fit, and I still needed to put the feet on some blocks so the cross bar would not touch the table.

This base is 20 mm tall and attaches with the standard screw locations. (hopefully. I printed the first section with 3mm holes and had to open them up with a drill, but since then have changed the model to 3.5mm) I recommend 20mm long screws and don't tighten them too hard or you could run them into the screen or the PSU cover. The threaded holes for the standard feet are modeled and I had no trouble getting the screws in for them. I did use some longer ones, but I think the stock ones should do well. If you use similar print settings, I don't see why they shouldn't work for you.

There are mounts for two 60x25 fans. I am using Noctua (NF-A6x25FLX) with the "low noise" filter to continuously pull air from the front to the back of the unit. (Only one pictured because I needed to order another one still.) They are wired up to the extra power supply taps and I suspect with them running full time, the PSU fan on time will be lowered even more.

The holes in the front are for a switch I found on Digikey (part number: PRK22J5DBBNN by ZF Electronics.) I use the one for my lights and haven't found a use for the other hole yet, but in the mean time it will just let more air flow through.

Printer:

Anycubic i3 Mega Ultrabase

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

Supports: Yes
I use Repetier-Host with Cura Engine
2mm thickness.

On a few of the prints, the y axis would bounce off the limit switch because the support is bigger than the actual part, but it didn't give me any issues, just a bunch of beeping and clicking every once in a while.

All together I used about 585g of plastic, but that should go down slightly bit since I lowered the fan mount a bit after I printed mine.
I basically used a ruler without zero at the end to make this thing, so I think it turned out pretty good fitment-wise.

comments.text: If anyone has suggestions for improvements or features, please comment.  I fried my main board (not related to this print) the day after I finished this so I haven't even been able to see how well it works. (I did one print after this part was installed.)

title: Guitar bridge to fix sharp intonation

description.text:
this is a bridge i designed for fixing bad intonation on cheap acoustic guitars. If the notes sharper as the strings are fretted higher on the neck this might fix it. If the action is too low with this bridge try increasing the scale in that dimension or adding paper under the bridge.

The guitar I designed it for was taken to a guitar shop where they said it was "unfixable" without moving the entire saddle and ruining the finish on the guitar. This bridge creates the lowest and farthest back action possible for my guitar.

If you would like the fusion 360 files or would like me to edit the design for your needs please contact me at my email in the bio.

Notes:

Use supports if printing in default orientation however it may be better to experiment with a different orientation to avoid the support fusing to the part if settings aren't dialed in for this kind of task

author: AWS3D

print_settings.Notes:: The 'Push' piece needs enough infill that there are more than 4 internal ribs. With just 4, there may be gaps at the joint between the wide cylinder and the narrow cylinder.

description.text:
Bulletin is a new product from Google.

https://www.google.com/bulletin/share

This is a 3D representation of the 2D logo of Bulletin.

The pushpin object is defined by the file Pushpin.scad - an OpenSCAD source file, a text file.

At the start of the file are a set of Boolean variables. Setting them to false hides that part of the object. There is one STL file for each part.

In the slicer, turn the 'Push' part upside down before printing.

Print each piece in the appropriate color.

Printer:

Monorice Mini Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

Varies.

Notes:

If you want to scale the model:

The red body piece takes a few minutes to render in OpenSCAD. Until it renders it will draw incorrectly (incorrectly in that it draws as the whole body, not just the red part.)

Scale the model by adjusting the scale=3 line in the OpenSCAD That way the alignment pin holes won't grow or shrink.

You don't need much infill, just enough that the sockets for the alignment pins are supported.

The 'Push' piece needs enough infill that there are more than 4 internal ribs. With just 4, there may be gaps at the joint between the wide cylinder and the narrow cylinder.

Glue the pieces together with cyanoacrylate glue.

Short pieces of filament go in the alignment holes to add strength.

I glued the yellow to the red, the green to the white, then the blue to the yellow+red body.

I made 3 at a time, so at this point I flipped everything over, and made the last glue joint, green to body, with the body on the table. I laid a ruler across the 3 white bases to help keep everything perpendicular, an added a few small weights (I used skateboard ball bearings) to give this last glue joint a bit of pressure as it dried.
This thing was made with Tinkercad.

Drift button that allows you to pull the handbrake without locking the ratchet.

Now you can perform those U turns that turns on teenager girls all over the world (as seen on top gear) without the fear to leave it locked

its designed for a Toyota Corolla AE86, with a barrel OD 13.7 and ID of 4.5, with 24 length

To mount it just unscrew the original handbrake button, remove the spring, and screw the drift button in.

to use, just pull the handbrake and the rear wheels will lock, and as soon as you release the handbrake, the reear wheels will spin again.
If you want to park the car, pull the button out as you pull the handbrake up, and the ratchet will lock as a regular handbrake. keep in mind to leave a gear engaged so that if, by any chance, the handbrake goes loose, you wont crash your car.

title: Cheap & Easy to Build Steel Filament Storage Rack - Store 80 Spools or more!

description.text:
I've been trying to come up with a heavy duty rack to store my filament rolls that is built well and doesn't break the bank. Today I found a solution that I love and I wanted to share it here on Thingiverse.

My solution was assembling a rack made of steel electrical handy boxes and 1/2in EMT conduit. It is extremely rugged, works perfect, and is extremely inexpensive to make. You can make a rack in about 10 minutes that holds up to 20 spools with $6.15 in parts. Once made, you can set it on a table, on a shelf, mount it to a wall, the possibilities are endless.

Basic Rack - Total Cost $6.15 - Holds up to 20 Spools
2x #5836134 Handy Boxes $.89ea // Link: https://www.homedepot.com/p/Single-Gang-Drawn-Handy-Box-1-7-8-in-Deep-with-1-2-in-KO-s-8660/100560024
4x #97271 1/2in EMT Connectors $.44ea // Link: https://www.homedepot.com/p/Halex-1-2-in-Electrical-Metallic-Tube-EMT-Set-Screw-Connector-96271/100204006
1x #101543 10' section 1/2in EMT $2.61ea // Link: https://www.homedepot.com/p/1-2-in-EMT-Conduit-101543/100400405

2x2 Rack - Total Cost $29.76 - Holds up to 80 Spools
8x #5836134 Handy Boxes $.89ea // Link: https://www.homedepot.com/p/Single-Gang-Drawn-Handy-Box-1-7-8-in-Deep-with-1-2-in-KO-s-8660/100560024
1x #2122 50pc 1/2in EMT Connectors $9.47ea // Link: https://www.homedepot.com/p/RACO-EMT-1-2-in-Insulated-Set-Screw-Connector-50-Pack-2122/203637583
5x #101543 10' section 1/2in EMT $2.61ea // Link: https://www.homedepot.com/p/1-2-in-EMT-Conduit-101543/100400405

Tools to Assemble:
Hammer
Flathead Screwdriver
Pliers
Hand Saw

For anyone not familiar with using conduit with electrical boxes, have a look at this video, it will show you how to put the connectors in the box. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i4pH4hUCT7g

Once all the connectors are installed in the boxes, simply cut the 1/2 EMT to length, install it in the connectors, and tighten the screws. For my 2x2 rack pictured above, I assembled 8 of the boxes with connectors. 4 similar to the one shown in the video, and 4 with the 2 inside connectors on the opposite side. I then cut 8 sections at 28in, 4 sections at 9in, and 4 sections at 6in. Then just put it all together. The nice thing with this design is you can use any length you want for the conduit. This makes it easy to make it fit the rack anywhere.

If anyone wants to keep going and make 3+ Tiers, you can use a Handy Box plate with a 1/2 Knockout: https://www.homedepot.com/p/RACO-Single-Gang-Handy-Box-Cover-with-1-2-in-Knockouts-25-Pack-861/202058330 and just keep going up!

The 2 STL files are for anyone that wants to put a blank plate on the handy box. One is a basic plate and the second has a spot where you can store your filament clips so you don't lose them. Each plate will need two #6 screws to attach it to the box.

IMPORTANT! Please keep in mind the box edges are sharp and can cut you. Also, I recommend wiping everything down with alcohol when done to get all the oil off. Definitely don't want oil getting on your filament. Happy Building!

description.text: Morse Taper 2 Male and Female

2018-02-15: Updated the filter towers a little bit, now better printable.
2018-02-16: Coarse Filter updated to V4, was a little bit too large, fits better now.

I love 3d printing but I hate the smell of it and some research papers indicate, that the flue might be harmful, so I designed this air filtration system.

Before you can install the filter, you need to cut a 116mm hole into the housing. If you put the fan into the filtertower, make some extra space for its cable. You will also need the following things:

  • a 120mm fan (mine can make up to 2000rpm, the fan should be powerful. Don't be scared, you won't hear it through the whole filter material).
  • some kind of coarse filter material (I used a pollen filter).
  • a fine filter of a vacuum cleaner (I used Rowenta ZR004801, any other filter with a size of 166 x 142 x 37mm or lower should work
  • and activated carbon filter (I used hh50705-v0parent activated carbon filters for cat-it cat toilets, 3-4 Euros at amazon). Any other filter with a thickness of up to 8mm and a size of 160 x 149mm will do.
  • 5 screws M3 x 14 and nuts
  • 4 screws for the filtertower itself, length according to housing and if you install a fan or not

The filter system consists of 3 types of filter which need to be installed in the following direction:

  • Everything goes into the filtertower. There are two versions: One has enough space to install a 120mm fan in it, another one is smaller, to have to install the fan under the filtertower. The tower can be printed without any support, put the side with the fan grill onto the heat bed. It will work, even my stock A8 printed it perfectly.

  • Coarse filter: That's the first layer of filtration. I used a pollen filter for my windows. But any thin filter material should work. Put the filter material in an cover it with the "coarse_filter_without_fan_V3.stl" or "coarse_filter_with_fan_V3.stl". If you don't install the fan on top of it, put 4 screws (up to M4) through all of it and also use these screws to connect the filter tower to the housing. The distance between the 4 holes is 105mm.

  • You can install the 120mm fan on top of the coarse filter and install it with the screws for the coarse filter and filtertower. You might want to use the fan frame stabilizers I uploaded: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2782394

  • Now put the fine filter on top. First you need to cut off the extra thing which is used to fasten it in the vacuum cleaner. Best use a small saw for it.

  • Put the activated carbon filter into the "activated_carbon_filter_bottom_V2.stl" and then put the activated_carbon_filter_top_V5.stl on top. The middle parts of both fit together pretty tightly. Use the M3 screws to fasten both parts together tightly. Now put it on top of the filter tower. This part of the system has not yet been tested, but I'm pretty sure it will work.

Any ideas, questions, suggestions? Just comment. You made one? I'd love to see some pictures! :)

Disclaimer: I don't know a lot about air filtration, I did some research, but I can not guarantee the efficiency of this filter system. You're responsible for yourself.

No

0.2

Infill:

I recommend 100%

Notes:

I prefer 100% infill, because I like some additional heft to this item. You can use less infill if you prefer. No supports should be necessary.

To complete the item, cut a single strip of felt that is slightly less than the width of the drip ring. The ring's interior has a crevice to allow for glue, so glue down the felt on the inside of the ring. Only one strip of felt should be necessary.

I recommend using burgundy colored felt, so that your drip ring doesn't take on new colors. You should be able to find it at any local crafts store.

To your health!

I have an office chair (brand unknown as it is a hand-me-down) that has three screws on the back for mounting a headrest. This is an attempt at making the headrest. I have not printed it out yet, as some of the parts are too big for my printer, so I will have to wait until my work printer is available.

You will need to print two of the thumbscrews (these are for optional height adjustment).

The parts all slide together with the exception of two parts - the long holes will line up and are meant to house a metal rod in each one. I am hoping that this will increase the strength of the parts when resting my head on the headrest.
A lot of work in Fusion 360

title: Pentacon 2.8/80 Projection lens to Nikon F-mount adapter

description.text:
This is an big tube adapter to fit on the front of a nikon camera and to screw a Pentacon 80mm ƒ/2.8 projection lens into. Get beautiful soap bubble bokeh for so much less than a trioplan lens.

This is not a generic pentacon mount to f-mount. This is one specific slide projector lens (pentacon 2.8/80 AV) to Nikon f-mount. There may even be different sizes of this one lens. This one had a barrel diameter a little over 51mm (over 2 inches)

This adapter comes in two parts that should snap together but you can glue together if you choose to. Has an internal tooth that fits into a groove on the projector completing a focusing helicoid. The lens can then be twisted to focus. The adapter also has a lip you could glue some scrap felt into to give some dampening.

If you need infinity focus you might have to cut off the last 5mm of the lens's plastic housing so the lens can move in closer to the camera. Be sure to protect the back element of the lens from being scratched while your are cutting. A scratched back element really wrecks the image.

Learning sketchup. Worked with beautiful 60 sided polygons.

For more mechanical adapters and to tweek designs better I think I will have to switch over to FreeCAD.

I think a lot of other projector lenses could be adapted the same way. Measure the diameter and build a tube for them. My f-mount stub is Ø42mm where it goes into this tube so it could easily be re-used to snap into other tube like adapters.

STL has been updated for M3 Bolt.

I liked the idea of Idig3d's Precision Thumbwheel (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2603493), so, I created my own.

Given that the Tevo Tarantula is smaller than the CR-10 the dial could not be as big. And thus I can't do numbers. But the concept is the same.

This was also done as part of my Overall Bed Design Project. Other parts are included here:
Y-Carriage: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2769679

How to Use the Dial

The pitch on the bed screws is 0.5, therefore 1/5 of a turn (the difference between every big nub, or spoke) is 0.1mm in height. The smaller nubs are separated by an angle that would give 0.02mm in height. This would work well if you have a feeler gauge.

title: Original Prusa i3 Filament Spool Holder

description.text:
UPDATE 02/07/18: Added V2 of both parts. Changed the frame grabbing outline. Should be easier to clamp on the frame, but I have not tried it yet.
The stock filament spool holder that came with my Prusa i3 MK3 was a little too bouncy for my taste. So I designed one to use two legs and 1/2" Sch. 40 PVC pipe.
I used Polymaker PETg because it's all I have besides PLA. I used 240C/80C, 15% infill, .30 layers, no support needed. Each one took about 1.5hours. Cut the PVC pipe to whatever length you want. 4 through 6 inches (102-152mm), or about 10 inches (250mm) max. If you cut the long PVC pipe you can hang multiple rolls. It's convenient for multi-color prints. This is tighter than the original. Use your thumbs to evenly push the bottom snap bump on and off the frame. Use even pressure and make sure you clean out the channels if they have a lot of blemishes. The slots need to be 6.3mm+

Another solid sculpture which needs to be printed in Corkscrew/Vase/Spiral (single wall) mode, no top layers, 5 bottom layers. You can also turn off vase mode and set it to print 2 (or more) side layers, zero top and 5 bottom layers.
I used PETg on my Taz6 and PLA on my Orig. Prusa i3 MK3.

There are two versions here. One has a cross pattern on the ends and the other is more square. The ones that are lit up in the photos are turned upside down and are using an LED base from my HexaFloraDeLuz design.

This is a tray that clips on to my kitchen faucet and holds a half-sponge to keep it off the counter and out of the sink basin. It has slots to drain drips out the front and is angled so that collected drips flow to the front edge.

After printing I coated the tray in Alumilite Amazing Clear Cast resin (which is FDA approved for repeated use food contact: FDA CFR 177.2600) to make sure that the whole thing is sealed so it doesn't grow mold or bacteria in the nooks and crannies.

(aside: I buy kitchen sponges from the grocery store and then cut them in half -- I find the smaller size to be better suited for cleaning dishes and the end result is the sponge ends up lasting about twice as long. Thus this tray is sized for a half a sponge rather than a full sponge. Give it a try!)

Printer:

Creality Ender-2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

20%

Sealing

3D printing leaves gaps and holes in the printed parts, as well as tiny crevices between layers. All these little nooks and crannies will become fantastic breeding grounds for bacterial, mold, or other nasties, so after making something that's going to be sitting in and around dirty water for years make sure to seal it so it can be sterilized and won't grow anything unpleasant. Also make sure that the sealant you use is non-toxic.

Titebond III wood glue is waterproof and FDA approved for applications like cutting boards, but it can be hard to get even layers and it'll make your piece look yellowish. I used Alumilite Amazing Clear Cast, which is also FDA approved and makes a nicer finished part, in my opinion. I'm also less worried about the casting resin peeling or scraping off over time.

To coat with the resin I mixed up half an ounce of resin, then -- wearing nitrile gloves -- spread the resin over all sides of the tray in a fairly thin coat. I left it on some painter's triangles to cure overnight.

title: Shaving Brush Travel Tube
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have previously played with similar designs on a travel brush tube for carrying a shave brush. I was able to create one by remixing a few other projects into something that worked for my particular brush. I wanted to build a design from the ground up using openscad so it was parametric and could be easily recreated for different height and width options. The result is what is attached.

To change the dimensions you can set 7 options:
diameter - the inside diameter of the brush tube
height - the inside height of the brush tube
vent_height - you can set the height of the venting (brush loft) and overrides percentageventing_height_percentage - how much of the brush tube is venting
parts - which part or parts of the travel tube do you want to create: all, lid, lids, tube
knurl_bevel - the bevel you want on your lid knurling
knurl_smooth - the smoothing you want on your lid knurling

By default it generated a tube and two lids (top and bottom). You can edit the parts variable if you want to generate the parts separately

PS - if the customizer errors for you, contact thingiverse please. It is a problem on their end. It works fine until it is published for some reason. You can download the openscad file and work with it directly in openscad to generate the travel tube you need.

Tired of my daughter's scooter scraping up my walls and creating a racket, I decided to design a kickstand to print on my MakerSelect Plus. It is four files to create five parts. In addition to the printed parts, you will need (2) 6-32 helicoils, (2) 6-32 x 3/8 screws, and (1) small spring approx. 1"x3/8". I have posted pictures of the parts that I used. I had to drill two holes in the main plate of the scooter, about 1/2" from the edge and 5/16" ctc. This matches the MOUNT file that has two holes that are sized to be tapped to accept the 6-32 helicoils. I have also included a MOUNT NO HOLES file that has no predetermined holes if you would like to use your own fastening method.

If you prefer to print the pin horizontal, it will require support as well. This may or may not be necessary. .3 Resolution and 100% infill for an under 2 hour print.
Parts Required:
Mount OR Mount no holes x1

Finishing:

These parts are designed to go straight from the printer to assembly. If your printer tends to print IDs on the small side, a radial file may be used to slightly open the pin hole on the mount. Not too much though as it is designed to be a friction fit, which holds the assembly together.

This design mimics the kickstands that come on select scooter products. It was designed using Autodesk Inventor
