description.text:
Spinning top modeled after a classic five spoke mag wheel.

Two STL file options.
Wheel Top BB: the tip is a hollowed out, requires super-gluing a 0.125" ball bearing in an attempt to minimize spin resistance.
Wheel Top no BB: Tip is complete. Print and use, no BB needed.

Printer:

Monoprice V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I usually do all I can to avoid printing with supports, but decided it was necessary here. I didn't want to print the wheel upside down as I wouldn't get the quality of finish I desired. So unfortunately support are needed.

Printed in black PLA. 20% infill seems to make a better top, keeping the weight down. You could even try it at 10%.

A bit of work to remove the supports, unfortunately. Painted with silver acrylic.

The shaft and tip need to be super-glued to the wheel. I tried to keep it a tight fit to keep it centered, so a small amount of sanding/filing might be needed. If you print the BB version, the recess for the ball may need to be opened up a little for a good fit.

Designed with TinkerCad. I borrowed the idea for the auto centering nub from Lain_Iwakura and his design here:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2720377

print_settings.Notes:: I would use PETG just because of the resistance to the elements, relatively low printing temperature and no need of a heating bed. The beauty of this is the simplicity, so if you have a few strings, you don't have to waste to much time trying to make it pretty.

description.text: This is my homemade anemometer that helped me out during hurricane Irma. What this is supposed to be is a spinning cup assembly that turns the shaft of a small electric motor to create voltage out the other side that can be tracked by a voltmeter or micro controller such as an Arduino Uno. It is made to fit most small motors and work with most size shafts. This design is compact and light, and fits inside of most bags. A vain could also be retrofitted if you choose, and the better quality motor you have, the more accurate your readings will be. I have supplied you with a draft of two options you can use to make yours. I want you to take this and make this!!!!! Please show me what you make!!!!!! I love to see what other people make from my ideas, and if you could like the video and subscribe in YouTube that would also be great!

Printer:

monoprice select

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

I Recommend 0.06

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I would use PETG just because of the resistance to the elements, relatively low printing temperature and no need of a heating bed. The beauty of this is the simplicity, so if you have a few strings, you don't have to waste to much time trying to make it pretty.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/zGgxj1yFeWA" ></iframe>
This is the manual option that requires you to test the voltage at diferant speeds and record the figures. I just stuck my head out of the car at 15, 30, 45 and 55 miles per hour and made a graph.

Hurricane Harvey

I had saw the damage that Harvey did to Texas, and saw Irma coming up fast towards me, and since we weren't evacuating I figured I would track the wind speed and set up a little weather station with my Arduino and barometer. My little anemometer picked up winds of 50 miles an hour. The 3D printed part is just the frosting on this little experiment. :)

This remix adds locking tabs to secure the top to the bottom, and to secure the bottom to the underside/backside of the hole. Also added a parameter to set the depth of the inside of the bottom part. I have not tested this yet! Please let me know if you have a problem.

The snaps are currently worthless--they snap off! Need redesigned.

If Thingiverse's Customizer is working, this is your best bet for customizing. If not,

  • Enable the Customizer according to https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/OpenSCAD_User_Manual/WIP#Customizer
  • Open the .scad file
  • Set your customizations
  • Render
  • Export as an STL file

description.text:
This is a laser sight to help make setting the X and Y origin (0,0) faster on a CNC router. This one is custom made to fit on my Probotix spindle mount - but I have included the Fusion 360 file so you can modify it to fit your machine. After attaching the sight to your machine VCarve an X with 0,0 being at the center of the X -- then turn on your laser to measure it's offset (I like to do this with the router raised up as high as it will go to get a consistent measuring height). Then you can simply use this offset (or its negative) and the laser to quickly set the X-Y zero point quickly.

To see the laser sight in action watch this video: https://youtu.be/l4VMo9DCzO8?t=23m36s (specifically the part at 23 minutes 36 seconds).

I printed this in PETG to withstand the hot temps in my garage in the summer months.

Hardware list (may not be complete):
Laser with red cross lines: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00BP42YMW
On/Off button: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01ESEEXXS

title: Aliens UD-4L Cheyenne Dropship
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the UD-4L Cheyenne Dropship from the movie Aliens. Another great product from Weyland Yutani supporting our Space Marines.

"In the pipe 5 x 5". Coming around for a zero seven niner."

There are many on the web but none of them were printable so I took one of the better models and broke it apart so that each component is printable and assembly is possible.

You will need to scale every part for your model.

Printing Tips:

  • Print the main body in the 3 pieces. Scale anywhere from 8 - 10% to fit your build area. All parts must be scaled to the same ratio.
  • Print 4 of the Exhaust Nozzle - I will update the body to include positional indicators at some time.
  • Split Missile Pods (L) and (R) - so you minimize surface scarring from support.
  • Missiles - will need support. You could split each one but that's a major PITA.
  • Canopy separated from fuselage. Allows you to print the canopy in clear or glow and glue to fuselage. V3 Fuselage fixes a gap in the old V2 version which doesn't impact the final print.

Update

  • Feb 10,2018 - Added new body with the fuselage lights cut out and the lights so you can print these in clear and glue them in. Adds to the realism of the model.

  • Feb 5, 2018 - Added a new V3 body which fixes a tiny gap between the canopy and fuselage. Also added a version with a separate canopy and a fuselage without the canopy so you can print the canopy in clear and then glue to the fuselage.

To fit on a Makerbot 2X build plate, I had to scale it to 8 - 12% - It depends on how big or small you want to make it. I am currently printing at 8%.

title: Lord of The Rings - Witch King Helm (lifesize)

description.text:
I cut the head piece into 3 separate files so that I could fit it on the bed of my CR-10 to make a full size wearable version that I scaled up 3440%. In hindsight I could have left the middle of the main spike on the forehead. This may be useful for someone, otherwise you can use meshmixer to cut the front and back as well and scale it up but leave the spike. I will add pictures when I am finished with the project, but that may be a while. I will be gluing, glassing, and then painting the helm to finish it up.

I tried to modify the files to make these changes but was not skilled enough to do so, at least in meshmixer.

The changes ill be making during the bondo step of the process will be:
-adding a little more height as the spike tapers off to the rim of the helm
-making the bottom spikes beefier similar to the movie prop
-making the head spikes beefier similar to the movie prop
-increasing the ridge on the cheek
-putting a square end to the inside of the eye pieces
-shaving a bit of the inside of the model down for room around my cheeks
-making the two spikes that come inwards towards the mouth area curve slightly up and a little larger
-straightening the end of the spike as it curves forward a bit in the model

update: I added the full .stl file without any slicing incase anyone wants to slice it for printing in different sections or if anyone knows how to remix it to correct the things I pointed out above

description.text:
Raid pass for Pokemon Go. Found a couple online that were a bit chunky and didn't look quite right. Put this together as my first project in Fusion 360.

Print, paint, glue.

I added a little pocket under the bottom cover so some simple LED's can be added for a glowing effect. I added hot glue to defuse the light. The cover acts as a switch with just some aluminum foil. When it is pulled away it breaks the connection.

Update:
I noticed a artifact on the Raid_Bottom.stl file for the original upload. I had a tolerance issue with my final print so I added a .5mm cut to add more space for the button batteries. This change was untested and I am not sure if it would affect the print. I have replaced the file with Raid_Bottom v2 which removes the cut and corrects the artifact. I have also uploaded v3 which has the bottom conduits(b) already on the print. This will eliminate having to print the 4 smaller parts and make the final assembly easier.

title: Mercedes Benz W168 Display console cover repair clip

description.text:
Every time you touch the inside of an old Mercedes some plastic part seems to snap off.
This is a clip to repair the plastic trim cover under the display console. This trim cover must be first removed to get to the fasteners for either the centre console or for the display console. This means it gets taken out frequently (every time a light bulb is changed in the dash display for example) and is likely to be damaged.

This clip is designed to replace broken off fastener clips to stop the cover being loose or rattling. The cover also contains the connecting rods for the odometer and clock controls so if the cover is loose, these functions are lost.

Panel is ABS-PS, so bond the repair clip to the panel with a good quality ABS compatible glue such as Single part Epoxy, Cyanoacrylate ie Super Glue (I highly recommend Loctite brand), or a two-part epoxy designed for ABS.

It doesn't really matter what colour you print the clip in since it is mounted below the panel and tucked well out of sight of normal viewing,

title: 40mm fan to 1.5" tube adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I bought a Printed Solid enclosure for fume and temperature control for my Lulz Mini. Built in to the enclosure is a 40mm fan mount to help vent fumes from the enclosure. I had some 1.5" sump discharge tubing leftover from a project and I wanted to use it to hook up to my fan. On here I found a lot of 1.25" adapters and a ton of parametric ones, but nothing specifically for 1.5". That's what this adapter is for.

The adapter prints clean and easy with no supports. I have a couple of thin ridges at the end for hooking up the tube. I printed it in PLA and it slipped right inside the tube tight enough to negate the need for clamps.

author: rogjalon

description.text:
The Tronxy X1 is a nice printer, but you have to do some adjustments. I found solutions for fixing the bed or for belt tighteners, but none to prevent x-axis wobbling, because you can't tighten one bearing. This small tightener solves this issue.

Additional parts:
1 screw M5 x 23 (cut the original one)
1 screw M5 x 7 or M5x10 and washers to compensate the screw length
1 screw M5 x 30 (tightener screw)
2 M5 nuts (one is mounted inside the tightener the other to fix the adjustment)
1 M5x19 headless screw (axis for the bearing, cut a longer one)

And you'll have to tap M5 threads into the inner and outer part

author: Lumorbis

description.text:
This is just the start of a much larger project, but it looks too cool not to upload for people to play with.  
This is my 2nd iteration using larger pins and fewer trusses.  It fit really well right off the printer, but 3/12 pins still broke.  
If you want to make your own the math isn't very hard.  Just make an even numbered polygon to the radius you want.  In this case it was 16 sides at 8".  That makes the beam angles 22.5 deg.  If it was a 24 sided polygon it would be 15 deg and so on.  
You'll need 16 of each to to make a full circle.
Printed using the same parameters as my socket organizer.

description.text:
Update 24/02/18: Added adjustable bltouch mount. Made the slot in the fan duct bigger so it fits the A8 stock blower fan a bit better.

Please consider leaving a tip or donating via paypal on my website: http://ferociousdesigns.co.uk/ if you like this design! All support is very much appreciated!

I designed this carriage to be easy to print and for people to be able to design simple modular extensions to accommodate different fan mounts, sensor mounts and belt holders. I have purposely left it fairly open for this reason.

Required Parts:
14x M3x5mm Pan head bolts
4x M3x8mm Pan head bolts
2x M3x12mm Pan head bolts
2x M3x20mm Cap head bolts
22x M3 Nuts
3x Igus Drylin RJ4JP-01-08 or equivalent bearings
3x 3mm wide cable ties

Printing:
It is totally up to you how to print, the parts all have nice flat edges to print them on or you could get creative if you wanted ;) I printed in PLA at 0.2mm layers with 25% cubic infill as I do with most parts. It feels strong enough like this.

Assembly:
Assemble as in the picture, it should all be pretty self explanatory.

title: Sega Megadrive / Genesis Case for Odroid XU4 Fan or Blue Heatsink

description.text:
This is a Megadrive case for the Odroid XU4 with Blue Heat Sink or fan. There are two versions of the uper part and you will need to choose between then depending on your XU4 version.

I have printed it at 0.1mm layer, PLA.

Print Black
1x Part_Up_BlueHeatsink.stl (or Part_Up_Fan depending.stl on your version)
1x Part_Down.stl
1x Cover_Emmc.stl
2x Feet.stl
1x Cartridge.stl
1x Button_OnOff.stl
1x Button_Volume.stl

Print Grey
1x Button_Reset.stl
1x Grey_Addon.stl

Print Red
1x Button_OnOff_RedLine.stl
1x Button_Volume_RedLine.stl
1x Grey_Addon_Light.stl

Print Gold
1x 16BIT.stl

Print the cartidge cover at a paper printer and glue it to the cartridge for more realism.

You will need to sand some little parts like buttons, grey addon, feet... to adjust them at those positions. Then you will have to glue them at the upper part.

After that you will need 4 screws M3 to join the up and the down parts. There are some positions for the M3 females, but ther are no necessary at all.

Finally you have to insert the EMMC cover at its position and the feet in the screws holes to hide them.

author: Josepsp

description.text:
April 2, 2014 Update:
In-flight test of new holder GimbalBase8 (GimbalBase7 did have a design flaw which would not allow to mount the motor ;-)). Still jello effect. Then Felix found the solution: Video recorded with 25 frames have jello, 30 some and videos with 60 frames are just perfect (http://youtu.be/Qj32H0mnQfI). Thanks Felix for this insight! Now the design process is finished. People report that they were not able get the rubber buffers from my previous post. It might be easier to get the M3 Flex-Loc buffers and use the Damper80 caps with M3/20mm screws in combination with the white stock buffers. I don't want to take credit for this damper design, as a similar one is used by other gimbal systems (check their product if 3d printing and soldering does not resonate with you ;-)). March 30, 2014 Update:
New design GimbalBase7 with vertical PCB mount, 8 mm increased distance from cam to ground, 9.5 mm diameter for original dampers, no holder for additional tracker, moved cam 5 mm backwards. This design is based on feedback and not yet tested in air. March 29, 2014 Update:
The key to the success of this gimbal is vibrational damping. The solution I use is to equip the stock dampers with a cap on each side (I added two parts, one for the top with 8 mm diam and one for the bottom with 7.5 mm diam), placing a 6 mm long rubber damper with M3 screw ends in the center. I had these dampers in my drawer but I don't have a part number or source. The other solution I saw on the web is to insert M3 Flex-Loc dampers (check google images) from the top into the stock dampers and a printed counter-part with a M3 thread from the bottom. Either solution leads to a siffer connection which is required to reduce oscillation. These are the PID params I currently use - they are not optimized yet but are good starting values. Comments are welcome... Roll: pwr 60, P 10, I 0.1, D 40
Pitch: pwr 50, P 10, I 0.1,D 40 Original Article:
I bought a brushless gimbal for a Hero 3 (same as this: http://www.ebay.com/bhp/gopro-gimbal) and modified it to hold the original DJI Vision cam. My first project with SolidWorks, so please excuse for flaws in the design ;-). Some details to the application: I use an independent GPS tracker which sits also on board of the gimbal base plate. The PCB is mounted with the parts facing to the plastic, thereby protecting them from contact with the camera. The sensor is mounted on the flat pad on top of the cam holder with double-sided sticky tape. The camera snaps into the holder - you need some force to bend the flaps aside, but I was able to put it in and out multiple times without braking the PLA. I get the power for the gimbal from the camera cable. I made a 3.5 mm 4-pin (important!) extension to the cam and split off the power. The shield carries Vcc and pin 3 GND. To clarify the connector pin-out: The tip and the adjacent ring are for the communication to the cam. The ring next to the shield is connected to Vcc (positive power). The base holder has a whole which serves to hold the female connector. The camera connects by a rectangular plug. See the images for more detail. Mounting is critical for success. First, the holder was designed to place the gimbal in a position which brings the center of gravity right in the middle of the Phantom. So, if you have different gear, you'll have to shift the holder. I attached the holder to the copter by stiff dampers (the original ones are too soft) and placed silicone pads between copter and base plate (see images). These pads are critical, as without you'll end up with un-dampened vibrations. I'm still working on this, so maybe someone has a better design? The space is tight and so the camera sits just a few mm above ground when facing a few angles up. So there's no need to modify the landing gear. The servo output connects to the RX-Pitch input of the gimbal by ground and signal only (don't connect 5 V). Tilting all the way down is possible. And finally, here are the SolidWorks 2012 files: http://www.stoeckli.net/?p=124
PLA, 50% fill

description.text:
This drag knife can be used to cut almost anything you would cut with a utility knife and it easly fits into your CNC router, making it a universal fit for almost any CNC router available.
The tool has been designed to use a utility knife blade which dramatically reduces the cost of consumable blades.
It can easily be clamped to your CNC router, for istance with a Stepcraft CNC machine, you may use an adequate ø 43 mm -> ø 20 mm adapter (https://shop.stepcraft-systems.com/adapter-d-43-mm-d-20mm-proxxon_1).
Both blade holders have an offset value of 2mm, anyway the exact value may vary from machine to machine and material to material. In general, if the blade is overturning at corners, reduce the offset. If it is under turning, increase the offset.

This is still a bit of a rough draft. The laptop chassis is my own design, using Microsoft 3D-Builder.

I randomly selected a fairly generic Rasberry Pi 3b case that roughly matched the rounded edges look that i had adopted (Pi_Case_Base.stl and Pi_Case_Cover.stl). I would love to link back to the maker of this thing, but have spent the last 2 hours searching Thingiverse for its page, with no luck. If anyone finds it, please comment me the URL and I will link to it.

It uses a simple/cheap bluetooth keyboard and the standard 7" touchscreen module.

The laptop chassis itself is made from two pieces. Its dimensions are exactly 22cm across, so it filled up the print bed of my Anet A8 completely, without a hair's width to spare. Because my printer had been rather poorly calibrated due to the addition of a Bowden extruder, I had to spend some time learning how to very precisely calibrate the coordinates of the home position. I printed it without support. I think it would work out much better with water soluble support material. The gap for the HDMI/USB connectors is a little bit off. I will definitely change that around next time. The hinge uses a 4mm rod, 20cm long. There seems to be enough friction to hold the lid in place (for now. Who knows what wear and tear will do).

This was really just an experiment. I know it needs work. I'd love to hear your suggestions and/or improvements.

My Start Script:

G21 ;metric values
G90 ;absolute positioning
G28 X0 Y0 ;move X/Y to min endstops
G28 Z0 ;move Z to min endstops
G1 Z50.0 F2000 ;move the platform down 50mm
G92 E0 ;zero the extruded length
G1 F200 E20 ;extrude 20mm of feed stock
G92 E0 ;zero the extruded length again
G4 S5 ;wait 5 seconds
G1 Y20 F2000 ;+20mm because of the front left screw

Lo scopo di questa prova è di progettare e realizzare un robot capace di muoversi autonomamente alla ricerca di sorgenti luminose collocate in posizioni fisse e sconosciute all'interno di un campo di movimento di dimensioni assegnate che presenta al suo interno degli ostacoli fissi posizionati casualmente, dunque il robot dovrà evitare tali ostacoli e rilevare un valore indicativo della quantità di vapori di sostanze solventi collocate in posizioni fisse all'interno del campo di movimento ed in particolare nell’intorno di fonti luminose, durante la prova il robot dovrà inviare ad un terminale, in tempo reale e mediante comunicazione bluetooth, i dati raccolti. Il robot avrà un tempo di massimo 7 minuti per individuare tutti gli obiettivi (fonti luminose e sorgenti di vapore). La prova si riterrà superata solo se, il robot avrà trovato tutte le luci e tutte le sorgenti di vapore entro il tempo prestabilito, più veloce è a trovarla maggiore sarà il punteggio. Durante la prova sono ammesse due sole possibilità di "deadlock" (blocco) del robot.

author: SimoneABNto

description.text:
About my pegboard:
I have buyed a pegboard from OBI (
https://www.obi.de/lochwandsysteme/lochwand-mit-vierkantlochung-1200-mm-breit/p/9178419).

This pegboard has square perforations with 1cm^2. This squares has the advantage for us owner of 3d printers that you can build your own set of items directly out of the printer.
The normal pegboards are only drilled with 3mm holes, so you need metal hooks because the prints will break with that thickness.

I am offering a series of all my prints for this pegboard for using or inspiration of your own items.

Please think about the needed density of your prints when you are slicing!
i have used PLA with a density between 25 and 50% (often with support, some items you have to clue befor using them). A resolution of 0.2 mm should be enough for your pegboard-items.

title: Earbud Wire Wrapper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Simple flat tool for wrapping earbud wires tidily. There are variations on the same theme.

The 4-point wrapper holds the earbuds separately and has enough space for an inline control device - place buds first.

The 2-point wrapper is a simpler version of the 4-point with space for an inline control device - wrapping plug first seems to be better.

The 3-point wrapper is actually smaller with little room for a controller - I found this useful for shortening cable lengths in whatever situation requires it.

The 6-point wrapper is a duplex version of the 4-point wrapper. I haven't done anything with this one but maybe you could wrap two sets - I don't know?

This is an model of the trusses of the Cage that served the student athletes of Phillips Exeter Academy from 1929 until 2014. During its 85 years of function, thousands of student athletes formed unique memories and thrived through priceless experiences while in that field house, such as my father who knows he cleared 13' pole vaulting only because he cleared the height of the raised track that ran around the perimeter (the blueprints disagree; the track was at only 10' 6").

I acquired the blueprints in late May of 2016 and started the model but I didn't have any motivation to finish it until the brand-new William Boyce Thompson Field House was opened on January 27, 2018 to much fanfare and excitement. The event was very well organized and respectful to the alumni who longed for the Cage while also being forward looking. My hope is that I can build a full model of the Cage to be placed in front of the Cage memorial in the lobby.

The process was fairly simple with many hiccups along the way. Initially, I intended to 3D print the model but the combination of difficult geometries and mediocre printers turned me towards laser cutting and then assembling it. Using Sketchup, I exported PNGs of the trusses, traced them in Adobe Illustrator and modified the resulting traces to make them laser cutter friendly. I then cut and hot glued the trusses together.
